sub_topic: Calculation of enthalpy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
Calculate the enthalpy change for the following chemical reaction: 

2NH3(g) + 3O2(g) → 2NO(g) + 3H2O(l) 

Given the following enthalpy values: 

ΔH°f (NH3) = −46.11 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (O2) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (NO) = 90.3 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (H2O) = −285.8 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change (ΔH) for the given chemical reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

For the products:
2 moles of NO: 2 × 90.3 kJ/mol = 180.6 kJ
3 moles of H2O: 3 × -285.8 kJ/mol = -857.4 kJ

For the reactants:
2 moles of NH3: 2 × -46.11 kJ/mol = -92.22 kJ
3 moles of O2: 3 × 0 kJ/mol = 0 kJ (since the enthalpy of formation for O2 is 0)

Now, substitute these values into the formula:

ΔH = (180.6 kJ + (-857.4 kJ)) - (-92.22 kJ + 0 kJ)
ΔH = (-676.8 kJ) - (-92.22 kJ)
ΔH = -584.58 kJ

The enthalpy change for the given chemical reaction is -584.58 kJ.
